Lead Communist Mexico in a glorious assault on the US, lead a Fascist Canada on a heroic quest to conquer Great Britain, lead a democratic Japan as she spreads peace freedom and democracy across Asia or just lounge about as a pacifist Soviet Union as the world around you burns. Hearts of Iron 4 is, at it’s core, about creating and playing out an alternate history. Leading a country, great or small, through the perils and pitfalls of the second world war era, you can follow the historical events if you wish and the game has a historical mode which will more closely follow events as they happened but the real genius of the game is in letting the player take another path.

As a relative newcomer to Paradox grand strategy it was somewhat intimidating at first, the sheer scope and scale is enough to stop even a veteran Axis and Allies player in their tracks. But give this game a bit of time and dedication and it will reward you with great steaming tanks full of entertainment!

Like most Paradox games they drop you into a vast complex simulation of nations and let you figure out what you want to do. Lead your country to glory or just try to survive as a small nation among the mayhem. Go for world domination or broker peace through diplomacy. Subvert governments and ferment revolution or fight for self determination. Focus on experimental technology, deploy rocket attacks and be the first to unleash the power of the atomic age… or just crank out a vast horde of infantry and bury your enemies in bodies.

To see how this all work in practice you can check out my series on youtube as I lead Mexico to its obvious destiny to conquer the Americas under the flag of the Mexican Socialist Republic! :)

reviewText:
I really enjoy the other Clausewitz titles: Europa Universalis IV, Crusader Kings II, Victoria 2.
Yet, I have never really liked the Hearts of Iron series. I found them too tedious, and honestly not very fun.
I have never liked a HOI game... until this one.

Hearts of Iron IV is a huge step up for the entire franchise.
Trading is a breeze - simple chart on what is produced - too much of and what you need more of.
Research is immersive - do I want to make Italy an air power, or achieve Mare Nostrum?
Conflicts and battles are intuitive - you can manually change the doctrine multiple times during each battle.
- On the overall map there are small color coded battle markers that tell if you are winning or losing (easy to give attention to the battles that matter while offering more time away from the battle interface)
Realistic companies (eg. Fiat for Italian tanks; Baretta for small arms)
Realistic machinery and accurate models.
Less cluttered interface with important popups occuring every 5 minutes instead of 5 seconds.

This game is far above any of the previous titles; I love it. It has reinstilled the WW2 fascination that I had when I was a kid.

Hearts of Iron 4 takes the wargaming genre to a new level with a masterful mix of in depth mechanical strength, solid visual representation and great WW2 simulation.

Full review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SImajYy1OTc&ab_channel=GuyLogic

Textual summary:
As always, watch the full video for the best possible impression.

While HoI4 has its problems, they really boil down to two things, which I’ll start off with. Firstly, performance is a nightmare. Once WW2 got rolling really well and a lot of units were getting fielded, and started running amok across my carefully crafted bunkers, I noticed framerates dropping below 20FPS.

While this isn’t a game of fluid animations and quick reactions, drops that big are still a big problem and my biggest critique on the title regarding its optimization. It truly starts to chug when things start getting hot on the world map.

The second issue is not an unexpected one from paradox…and that is that the tutorial is ♥♥♥♥ poor. It barely explains the base UI Concepts and gameplay idea’s while throwing you into the deep end, so going in you can expect to be reading the wiki, watching the YouTube video’s and reading the 30 page manual if you want to get stuff done with any competence.

Having said that – the game has a ton going for it, outside of the obvious and ever-loving support for the modding scene. My main love for this game is that it allows deviation from historical accuracy if you desire to do so.
You can to go democratic Germany? Fascist USA? Japan Allied with America to take out China? YOU CAN! Obviously, you can also go for historical accuracy for the Ai.

Further, a normally very subpar part of a wargaming title is the graphical representation of the units, combat and various zones of control…. HoI 4 does a phenomenal job using great visual and audio design to convey information about units, compositions, positions, defenses, land type and so on.

It takes very little time to get an intuitive grasp on the visual side of things and translate that to possible action to can and should take. The game doesn’t trade in mechanical depth in any form for this either, a true win-win situation.
Further, while the diplomacy can feel restrictive if you pick a minor power to play with, because you are locked out of many conflicts early on, you can still choose to play an unorthodox pick like The Netherlands or other minor nations, allowing for much more replay ability and deviation from the “norm” than you would have otherwise.

Lastly, the depth and complexity you want and desire in a wargaming title is here, and that means proper planning, execution and managing the entire geo-political situation is perfect to a T.

Wonderful game and aguably the most solid title Paradox Interactive has ever launched.

Although it's being criticized, I feel that the switch to a more sandbox and slightly less railed WWII experience provides both historical grognards and world war microbebies a chance to live out their strategic dreams.

Come on, Neo-Ottoman Empire? That's friggin' awesome.

However, for all of the progress made in the field of accessibility and player inclusiveness we still have a ways to go. I say this for the thousands of people who are looking at HOI4 or have purchased HOI4 with no experience with Paradox grand strategy games. The Italy tutorial, while better than the one included in HOI3, lacks serious depth. If a newcomer were to hop in and play only the tutorial, then pick a major power, they would be screwed.

A very small nitpick and I understand that in a sense, I'm trying to have my cake and eat it too. You can't have grand strategy without complexity but newcomers could use a little more information! They shouldn't have to rely on the wiki for basic info about game mechanics. (Like how to use your navies, something completely absent from the tutorial. Or how to increase the reinforcement limit of airwings so you can continue to fill them with the planes you're producing, or how to manage occupied territories and switch occupation methods, etc...)

I feel that for the in-game tutorial to be successful the player should be left with enough information to hop into the game as a major power and have some idea of what they're doing. The fact that the tutorial doesn't cover all types of warfare, land, sea, and air is just inexcusable. Make Jake's entire job working on tutorials with that sweet sweet glaswegian ASMR voice of his.

Either way, I love this game and see myself playing it for a loooong time to come.

The real deal. Even at this early stage, I can see it's the strongest WWII simulator around.

Started as facist Japan in 1936 (I chose veteran/ironman despite having no prior HOI experience), found myself in control of large swaths of China, Korea and a dozen or so islands (as would be accurate for the time). I quickly allied with Germany and Italy who had no trouble arranging terms with me, I now have military access to those countries if I desire. I do have one ally in the form of Inner Mongolia, a pro-Japan puppet state.

Currently working on promoting the facist party in the Philipines (itself a puppet state of the US) and building an army to attack both Chinese factions. As Hirohito I'm promoting Chinese border tensions as part of my Japan focus tree. Let's see how it goes, it's only been a few months in-game!

I would only recommend if you can get past the complexity (by far one of the most complex games around) and you're interested in history + willing to do research - otherwise, don't bother.

And oh yes, the music is phenomenal. I can't wait for the mod music for some historically accurate songs.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Hearts of Iron 4 makes great improvements upon its predecessor, Hearts of Iron 3, while still being as complex and difficult. HOI4 allows for more replayability, as it allows for more alternate history scenarios compared ot HOI3.

The atmosphere of the game is amazing and immerses you in the world war 2 era. The music, loading screen art, and art style sets the appropriate mood for the game. The graphics are the best Paradox has ever done so far. The interface also feels fluid and organized. The battle plan mechanic is revolutionary - you won't have to tediously micromanage hundreds of divisions like in HOI3, but it doesn't feel like everything has been oversimplified either.

However, there are still some flaws. The battle plans can get wonky when fighting in unusual geography. My battle plans were messing up near the great lakes region in North America, for example. Also, there is a lack of map modes and information interfaces in the game. For example, you can't check how much manpower or industry a country has, even if they are your ally.

Pros:
- UI
- Graphics & art style
- Complex, but not overwhelmingly difficult to master

Cons:
- Lack of map modes
- Lack of information (no ledger like other paradox games)

reviewText:
It's a pretty good game, but HoI3 with all its DLC is still superior.

There's quite a few things that I do not like about HoI4... For one, there's no organic NATO symbols, so one is forced to use a mod for them. The map and units are quite confusing and jumbled because of this. It's difficult to actually tell what's going on in any sort of timely manner. Some of the controls are confusing and jumbled as well. Figuring out how to use air power effectively is a real headache, as well as trying to figure out what to do when one actually wins a war.

Then again, there's a lot of things that are really good about HiO4 as well. The ability to create fronts, armies, and plans for use by one's armies is really cool, but need a little work too. The graphics are really good, as is the sound. Many of the panels are pretty steamlined, but it still seems to be missing some things too- like espionage, and intelligence and the like.

Overall, this is a great start to what can be an amazing game- it needs a lot of work, and there's plenty of room for expansion too!

reviewText: Honestly, it's unfinished, still, after like 2 extra years of development. The battle lines suck, and have almost no options for you to customize your army's movements, the airplane interface is confusing and wonky, the naval interface is weird and undescriptive, and the whole thing lacks any sort of indication as to what you are doing. The AI is horrific, the limitations invisible, the bugs are everywhere (Japan sent no troops to Europe in my game, but was somehow able to vassalize Luxembourg, who then swallowed France for me, and there is no command console option to take my provinces back because you need province IDs which aren't available yet) the controls change randomly (some functions you right click for, sometimes you left click, even if it's the exact same function the only difference is a change in interface). Some features are unfinished, for example the national focuses (there should be more than 7 specific ones, come on), the balance is off (France and Italy are powerful in this game, and nationalist Spain is ♥♥♥♥) and other things that you think they would have noticed sooner than they did.
